title: Relative Clauses - Which, That or What 4
instructions: Complete the sentences with the appropriate relative pronoun, B1whichB2, B1thatB2 or B1whatB2.

remarks: Corr: what. There's no noun to refer back to, so only 'what' is correct. The verb 'accuse sb of sg' has two objects, and here the second is a noun clause starting with 'what'.

sentence: Max wanted to buy the newspaper
remarks: Corr: which or that. We refer back to a noun 'the newspaper', so we cannot use 'what'.

sentence: the doctors haven’t found a word for.
remarks: Corr: what. Here there's no noun to refer back to, so we cannot use 'which' or 'that'.
Corr: what. Here there's no noun to refer back to, 'what' comes after a verb (joke about).
Corr: which or that. Here we refer back to a noun 'the virus', so we cannot use 'what'.
Corr: what. Here there's no noun to refer back to, so we cannot use 'which' or 'that'.

sentence: you can never be a good programmer.
remarks: Corr: which. We refer back to a noun (skills), so we cannot use 'what'. We cannot use 'that' either because it cannot be used after prepositions, and here we have 'without'.

sentence: you got off is quite far away from the building
remarks: Corr: which. We refer back to a noun (bus stop), so we cannot use 'what'. Here we cannot use 'that' either because there's a preposition (at), and it cannot be used after prepositions.
Corr: which or that. We refer back to a noun (the building), so we cannot use 'what'.
Corr: what. Here there's no noun to refer back to, so only 'what' is correct.

sentence: He had read most of the books
remarks: Corr: which or that. We refer back to a noun 'the books', so we cannot use 'what'.
